<<Accounts>>

Let's start with a name for your budget. This is completely customizable, so let's make it something fun and exciting. If you can't think of anything now, you can always change it later. ChatGPT came up with some fun ones:

Fund-a-licious
Money Mojo
The Dollar Dash
Budget Bonanza
highlight: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

Click on the arrow and select "Rename Budget". Make sure to click Enter when you've chosen a name.
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

The plus side to having your transactions automatically imported is that it will save you time. The downside is that it requires additional setup and SimpleFin requires an additional fee.

<<Accounts>>

You'll see that there are three options:

1. Create a local account (used if you want to add transactions manually)
2. Link a European bank account
3. Link a North American bank account

The last two are used if you would like to link to your bank and have transactions automatically imported into MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

Now we're going to add an account. Select "+ Add Account".
highlight: add_account
Budget Summary Overview
Cancelled the transaction!

<<Accounts>>

Notice that once you add a transaction, MyBudgetCoach assumes that you immediately want to add another one. You can choose to continue adding another transaction or click "Cancel" to move forward. For now, let's click "Cancel".

<<Accounts>>

Look at you! You've added your first transaction!

<<Accounts>>

Notice how the account balance is $100 less.

<<Accounts>>

Now let's take a look at some of the features that come with transactions.

<<Accounts>>

When you add a new transaction, the system defaults to "Uncleared". This checkbox is gray, which means the transaction has not cleared in your bank account yet.
I cleared the transaction

<<Accounts>>

Let's pretend you checked your account and ta-da! The transaction has cleared. Click this box to turn it green. This indicates that the transaction has "Cleared".
It's been cleared!

<<Accounts>>

Let's enter another transaction, but this time it'll be for money coming INTO the account. This includes income, refunds, or transfers FROM other accounts.

<<Accounts>>

The Cleared total now matches the account balance and the Uncleared balance is 0.
Budget Table Overview

<<Accounts>>

Select the check boxes to the left of each transaction. This will highlight the row blue.
Goodbye transactions!

<<Accounts>>

At the top right next to the Search bar, you'll see purple text that reads "2 transactions". Click on the arrow and then choose "Delete".

<<Accounts>>

You're doing awesome! With more practice, you'll be a pro at this in no time.

Next
financial_goal = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Well, look at that [[user_first_name]]! We're ready to move on to Step 3! But, before we continue, let me ask you a question. 

What is a financial goal of yours? What is something you would like to save for over time?
I pivoted!

<<Accounts>>

That is a fantastic goal! Now we're going to "Pivot" on over to the "Budget" screen. Click "Budget" in the left menu under your budget name to continue.

Next
accomplish = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

Perfect! Welcome to the Budget screen. In Step 3, we will be doing a Budget Tour & Setup. I have another question for you. What do you hope to accomplish with budgeting?

<<Budget>>

Thanks for sharing with me! That is a great reason for wanting to gain clarity and control of your finances.

Now, let's start working on your budget!

<<Budget>>

We're going to start with a tour of the Budget screen. Here you can see the current month, as well as previous and future months.
That's easy.

<<Budget>>

This is a great feature if you want to see what you've spent in previous months and plan ahead for future months.
Add Transaction
I'm at the edge of my seat!

<<Accounts>>

Me too, my friend. Me too. 

We'll dive into it more when we cover How to Add Transactions

<<Accounts>>

When clicking "Show running balance", a new column is added to the right. This shows the account balance after each transaction, which comes in handy when making sure your account balances are accurate.

<<Accounts>>

"Export" allows you to download all of your transactions as a CSV file. This is a great feature for those who like data and spreadsheets.

<<Accounts>>

"Reconcile" is what you do to confirm that you budget account on MBC matches your bank account in real life. It's important to add transactions and reconcile regularly to avoid too much overwhelm and playing catch up at the end of the month.
Stop! You're making me hungry!

<<Accounts>>

Under the "Category" column, select Categorize and select "+ Create Category" at the bottom. A box will pop up prompting you to choose a category name and group. Type in Groceries and choose "Usual Expenses" as your category group. Click "Confirm". Then, choose Groceries from the category dropdown menu.

<<Accounts>>

"Link Account" is where you will go if you choose to link your account to the bank. There's no need to delete and re-add the account.

favorite_hobby = [user_input]
Really? Why is that?

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach is a zero-based budgeting software, which means that every dollar in your budget has a job. But, MBC is unique from others.
Let's do this!

<<Accounts>>

I love that! Let's get started, shall we?
...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...
Of course
Can you answer 3 short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!
I submitted the form
Great! Here's the link: https://airtable.com/appYAaDkGzB3ecOzl/shrUnpE9sHBWWDMyB
Thanks so much! Happy budgeting!
User Survey after Tutorial
I'm feeling great!

<<Accounts>>

Welcome to MyBudgetCoach [[user_first_name]]! I'm so glad that you're here and ready to gain clarity and control around your finances. The journey ahead won't be easy, but the fact that you're here means you are ready to put in the work. I'm curious, have you ever tried budgeting before?
Budget Setup

<<Budget>>

The Spent column shows what you've actually spent. This gives you true awareness of your spending vs. guessing.
I don't want that.

<<Budget>>

I highly recommend choosing the option to "Cover overspending". If you choose to rollover the overspend, you take away from next month's budget. If the overspend continues every month, it will eventually snowball and you'll end up with a large negative balance for that category. You also risk over-drafting your account or find yourself needing to use your credit card.

<<Budget>>

You have the same options for categories with money leftover at the end of the month. You can transfer the funds to a category that is negative or put it towards a different category. You can also rollover the funds to the next month.

<<Budget>>

If you find that you are always overspending in the same category every month, you may need to adjust how much you are allocating to that category.
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

For the purposes of this tutorial, we are going to start with manually entering your transactions. Once you get more familiar with MBC, you can view the "Import Transaction Options" conversation for different options on importing transactions.

<<Accounts>>

"Close Account" allows you to delete an account out of MyBudgetCoach if you no longer want or need it. 

Please note: this button won't affect your actual bank accounts in real life.
Did the dance!
Not really feeling the dance.

<<Accounts>>

That was a lot!

Step 1 complete! Get up and celebrate with your best "Monica" dance!

<<Accounts>>

You're doing great! Remember, you can always take a break and come back when you're ready. I'll be waiting...

<<Accounts>>

Step 2 is How to Add Transactions. 

In this step, you'll actually get to practice adding transactions to your account. Start by confirming that you are still in your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

For checking account transactions, payments will DECREASE the balance and deposits will INCREASE the balance.

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and click on "+ Add New".

<<Accounts>>

You should see the calendar box pop up. Go ahead and choose today's date.
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

In the meantime, these arrows allow you to expand or collapse any split transactions. You can collapse them for a cleaner view or leave them open to get the full picture. Since you don't have any split transactions, it won't do anything just yet.

<<Accounts>>

These three dots give you even more options! Let's talk about some of these.

<<Accounts>>

"Hide cleared checkboxes" removes the column that shows the cleared (green) and uncleared (gray) checkboxes next to your transactions. These are just reminders of what has cleared in your bank vs. what is still pending

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare multiple months at once. You can click on the calendars to view one, two, or several months at a time. Go ahead and play around with it by clicking the different icons.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, then you've overspent for that category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available. We'll talk more about this later.

<<Budget>>

To help keep the Categories organized, they are housed under Category Groups. These are the rows with bold text.
highlight: balance_column
How fancy!

<<Budget>>

Now you can view multiple months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
Paycheck entered!

<<Accounts>>

Start by clicking "+ Add New". Follow the below steps:

1. Choose today's date and click "Add"
2. Payee = Employer
3. Category = Income
4. Deposit Amount = $500

<<Accounts>>

You should have two transactions entered. One is cleared (green) and one is not (gray). Click on your account balance.

<<Accounts>>

You'll see that the Uncleared balance is $500 and the cleared balance is $100. Go ahead and click on the gray checkmark for the income transaction you just entered. This clears it and turns it green.

<<Budget>>

If you go to the right of the header "Category", you'll see three vertical dots. Click on those. This will give you the option to "Expand" and "Collapse" Category Groups, as well as show and hide any Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

For example, I do all my grocery shopping on the weekends. I budget $800/month for my family of four, which gives me about $200/week. However, some months have a fifth weekend. So, instead of being able to spend $200, I'm reduced to spending $160 to account for the extra week.

<<Accounts>>

Sorry. Where are my manners? I'm Jessica! You're virtual avatar. I was created by the real-life coach to be available to you 24/7. While I love budgeting and sharing that passion with others, I also love spending time with my teenagers, speed puzzling, baking, and sleeping. Lol! I know, super exciting. What is your favorite hobby?
Budget Skills
Excel/Google Sheets
Budgeting Software
Awesome! What budgeting method have you tried?
Awesome! Glad you're here.
Tell me more!

<<Accounts>>

As I mentioned before, your budgeting journey won't be easy. It'll require learning new skills and mindset shifts. But, that's where the real-life me comes into play. There are two ways to get in touch with me.
What's the second choice?

<<Accounts>>

The first is through the Message center. It's in the menu there to the left under Schedules. Please feel free to message me at anytime. I will do my best to respond within one business day.
I can't wait!

<<Accounts>>

Zoom is another great option to connect with me. However, there is an additional charge of $35/hour for Zoom calls. We can talk about anything you want - budgeting, debt, goals, etc. That's what I'm here for.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Let's talk about some other functions within MBC. In the bottom right corner of this chat box, you'll see three dots. If you click on that, it will bring up three options - Give Feedback, Reset This Conversation, and End This Conversation.

<<Accounts>>

Note: I am NOT a chatbot and cannot answer your questions during this tutorial. Please use the already discussed methods to reach out for any questions.

<<Accounts>>

I'm so glad you asked! Under my picture to the left is a white box that should currently be labeled as "Introduction". When the chat box is closed, it'll say "Continue conversation". Click the box to resume our conversation. When the chat box is open, it'll say "In progress" until you complete the tutorial.

<<Accounts>>

You can also start a new conversation by clicking on the white text that reads "Start a New Conversation". However, I highly recommend completing the introduction before moving forward with a different conversation, and only when you are ready for more.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we've completed the features overview of MyBudgetCoach, let's move on to the more exciting, actionable steps of MBC.

<<Accounts>>

Okay! Right on!

highlight: add_account

<<Accounts>>

For now, you won't add any credit cards. I would love for you to spend some time mastering these new skills within your checking account first. When you feel confident with that, you can go to "Start a New Conversation" on the left and select "Add Credit Card". This will start a new conversation/tutorial for how to add a credit card.
Going strong!

<<Accounts>>

How're you doing? You still with me?
That's okay. That's why there's a built in "Back" button.
Let's do this!

<<Accounts>>

Next on the agenda... a tour of your account screen.
I've selected it!

<<Accounts>>

Let's make sure you're in the checking account that we just set up. Click into your checking account if you are not already there.

<<Accounts>>

Perfect! Below the name of your account, you will see the account balance, which should currently be at $0. Click on the double arrows to see a breakdown of the cleared and uncleared totals. We'll get into these more in depth later.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

This button allows you to upload a CSV file of your bank transactions. Directions on how to do this will be under the "Import Transaction Options" conversation to the left, however, feel free to reach out if you need help.
highlight: import_button

<<Accounts>>

The "+ Add New" button is where you will manually add new transactions for this account.
Will do!
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

The "Filter
 button allows you to view transactions based on certain criteria that you can set. Click it to see the many options, and feel free to play around with it once you start adding transactions.
highlight: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

Next to the Filter button, is the "Undo" and "Redo" buttons. Mistakes do happen after all. We're only human, right?

<<Accounts>>

The search bar helps you find transactions based on date, category, transaction amount, or payee. This will come in super handy when you're trying to dig through hundreds of transactions just to find a specific one.
highlight: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

One of my favorite features of MBC, and the one I use most, is the "split transaction" feature!
Been there!

<<Accounts>>

I know right!?! It's great for those times when you make a trip to Target for groceries, but leave with groceries, maybe some cleaning supplies, and, oh yeah... my child's birthday is tomorrow.
highlight: split_toggle_button
highlight: more_button
LOVE IT!
That's completely fine.
That's a great place to start.

budget_software = [user_input]
Which software did you use?
Yeah... But, who are you?

<<Accounts>>

Because it comes with a virtual avatar (that's ME!) that will guide and encourage you through the process of budgeting and celebrate all the amazing progress you make along the way. Pretty cool, right?
I renamed by budget!
Payee entered!

<<Accounts>>

Now click on "Payee" and enter your favorite grocery store. Mine is Costco. Since we're starting from scratch, click "+ Create New Payee".

<<Accounts>>

For now, we're going to leave the "Notes" blank. However, this is a great place to leave a memo for yourself for any transactions that you might need to come back to.
highlight: select_category
Holy cow!

<<Accounts>>

Since you spent money at the grocery store, it's considered "Payment". Type $100 in that box.
highlight: payment_input
I've added the transaction!

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and save this transaction. We'll come back and delete it later. To save it, click "Add".
highlight: save_transaction
highlight: account_balance
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: deposit_input
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

But Coach, why does this matter? 

Let's say you spend money but it hasn't hit your bank yet. However, you'll want to factor that spending into your budget.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

You can manually enter the transaction, leave it as "uncleared", and it'll update your budget to show the true balance in your bank account. Just make sure you "clear" that transaction once it hits your bank.

<<Accounts>>

Before we delete these transactions, let's go over how to split a transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Let's use our grocery store trip as an example. When choosing a category, you'll see green text with opposite arrows that reads "Split Transaction". Click on it.

<<Accounts>>

Your transaction added a second row. Let's say I spent $75 towards groceries and $25 towards household supplies.

<<Accounts>>

Please follow these steps, but keep in mind that you will need to create a new category for Household Supplies:

1. Category = Groceries
2. Payment = 75 
3. Click "Add Split"
4. Category = Household Supplies
5. Payment = 25
6. Click Enter
Nah... I got this!

<<Accounts>>

You did it! You split your first transaction! Not too tricky, right?
I knew you could do it!
That's okay. Feel free to use the "back" button to repeat the process or you can always send me a message or schedule a Zoom call.
I still don't understand.
Yes, please!

<<Accounts>>

Time to delete these fake transactions!
highlight: months_band
highlight: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

For this tutorial, we're just going to focus on a single month. Please click on the first calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget".
Got it!

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on this highlighted number for now.

It will be purple if you have a positive or no balance ($0) and red if you have a negative balance.
highlight: budget_header
highlight: budget_header
That's easy.

<<Budget>>

If you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse and expand the budget summary view.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the month, there are three vertical dots. Clicking on these shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click. These include "Copy last month's budget" and "Set budgets to 3 month average".
highlight: budget_more_button

<<Budget>>

Please note, that the option to "Set budgets to zero" will remove any budgeted dollars and reset everything to $0 for that month.

<<Budget>>

Bummer, huh? Let's keep moving.
That seems complicated.

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table. It's similar to the old school cash envelope system, but digitally! You'll get to create categories relevant to your life and budget them accordingly.
highlight: budget_table
Great! This is one of my favorite parts of setting up a budget.
It's okay. We'll walk through it together.
I'm excited!

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category, or envelope. Remember when we added the split transaction for groceries and household supplies? Well, those categories would be under this column. We'll customize these more in a bit.
highlight: category_column

<<Budget>>

The Budgeting column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows how much money you have allocated to each category for a specific time period, whether that be weekly, bi-weekly, or monthly.
highlight: budgeted_column
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

As I mentioned before, your budget is comprised of categories that help organize your dollars. You can have as many or as few categories as you'd like.
highlight: category_column

<<Budget>>

As an important note, you cannot delete categories that have previous transactions linked to it. You will be prompted to re-label those transactions in order to actually delete the category. The Hide feature is used when you're done using a category and no longer want to see it.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. This gives you the option to Hide, Rename, or Delete a category or category group. You can also "Add category" to a category group.

<<Budget>>

You will also see a small paper icon for each row. Clicking on this opens up a Note box. This can be helpful to capture information about that category, such as the due date or the intended budget amount each month.

<<Budget>>

I'm so proud of the progress you are making! Just as a reminder, you can always take a break and come back when you're ready for more.
Yes, but not a duck.

<<Budget>>

Fun question... do you have any pets?
Lol! I kind of figured. Do you have cats or dogs?
That's okay.
I'm more of a cat person myself.
I have one of those. She's a Puggle and a hot mess.
Oh my! Busy house.

<<Budget>>

So, let's start customizing YOUR budget. But first, let's get rid of these default category groups.

<<Budget>>

Remember when you said that [[favorite_hobby]] was your favorite hobby? Let's add that to your budget. I'm going to add a category group called "Variable Expenses".

<<Budget>>

Perfect! We've got your first category group and category set up. Variable Expenses is used for things that you may or may not spend money on every month.

Next
streaming_service = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

You also mentioned that you like watching [[favorite_tv_show]]. What streaming service or cable provider do you use to watch [[favorite_tv_show]]?

<<Budget>>

Great! Let's add [[streaming_service]] to your budget. We're going to create a category group called Fixed and Recurring Expenses. Let's get that set up.

<<Budget>>

Fixed and Recurring Expenses is used for bills with a set amount and set due date. While some utility amounts may fluctuate from month to month, they are still due on the same day every month.
I need help again.

<<Budget>>

Let's do one more, but this time, you're going to add it. Let's add a category group called "Daily Spending". Let me know when you're done.
Click on "Add Group". This can be found at the bottom of the budget table before the Income section.
Great job! Daily Spending is used for things that you purchase every month, but the amounts and purchase dates will vary from month to month, like groceries.

<<Budget>>

Your budget is really coming along. Just a reminder, this is YOUR budget and is completely customizable to your needs and lifestyle. I am going to help you get started by adding a few more groups and categories.

<<Budget>>

Just to point out, I did add some hypothetical due dates to your Fixed and Recurring Expenses. Having these included is a good way to track which bills will need to get paid with each paycheck. They're also listed chronologically.
I clicked and dragged!

<<Budget>>

Oops! The Electric Bill should be before the Water Bill. That's okay. Easy fix. Simply click and drag to move it where it belongs.
That's helpful!

<<Budget>>

Remember when you mentioned that [[financial_goal]] was your financial goal? Well, I went ahead and added that under the group labeled "Goals".
There were?
I did notice.

<<Budget>>

Before we continue, I wanted to point out a couple sections in the Budget Table that you may have noticed: Income and Starting Balances.

<<Budget>>

The Income section is generally the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month. This could also include any deposited cash or refunds.
Lol! Yep!

<<Budget>>

The Starting Balances section is calculated your first month, but remains at $0 each month after that. You can Hide the category if you would like after your first month.
Let's do this!
I think I need a break!

<<Budget>>

Look at that [[user_first_name]]! We are moving right along. We are officially on the last step: Budget Skills.
Go for it! I'll be here when you get back.

<<Budget>>

In this last step, we're going to talk about how to actually budget your dollars.

<<Budget>>

There are a few ways to move your dollars into the categories that you just set up. But first, we'll need to add your bank balance.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

Log in to your bank and find the account balance. Make sure you are in the correct checking account in MyBudgetCoach. Let me know when you've got this.

<<Accounts>>

You're going to add a new transaction. Please follow the below steps:
1. Date - use the current date
2. Payee - can leave blank
3. Notes - can include if you want
4. Category - Starting Balances
5. Deposit - use the account balance

Then, click Add.

<<Accounts>>

There you go! You now have money in MyBudgetCoach that we can start budgeting into your categories.

<<Budget>>

The first way to move money in MBC, is by clicking on the purple number under "To Budget" and select "Move to a Category".

<<Budget>>

A box will pop up asking you to enter a dollar amount and to select which category you want the money moved to. You can use the dropdown menu or just type in the category. Now click "Transfer". Easy peasy!
Okay. I've moved money!

<<Budget>>

Just as a note, this is just transferring money from the larger To Budget amount to your "envelopes" within MyBudgetCoach. Nothing actually moves in your bank account.
That's simple.

<<Budget>>

Another way to budget your money, and my personal preference, is to click into the "Budgeted" column. Pick a category you want to fund and then click into the "Budgeted" cell for that row. Simply type how much you want to fund, and you're done!
highlight: budgeted_column
I've been there before.

<<Budget>>

The last way you can move money around is between categories. Let's say you want to move dollars from one category to another directly. An example of this would be when you need some extra money for groceries, and plan to take it from your Dining Out envelope.

<<Budget>>

In the "Balance" column, choose the category that you want to move money FROM. Click on the dollar amount and select "Transfer to another category". Enter the amount that you want to transfer and select which category you want to move that money TO. Click "Transfer" when you're done.
Makes sense.

<<Budget>>

Please note: for this to work, money must already be assigned to the FROM category before you can transfer it to another one. In short, you can't move money from a category with $0.
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

Ta-da! You just learned the three ways to move your money around. Now, I want you to take a few minutes to give the rest of your dollars a job. Remember, MyBudgetCoach is a zero-based system, so make sure not to leave any money in "To Budget".
Oh, right!

<<Budget>>

Another reminder, if you need to undo something, you have those handy "undo" and "redo" buttons on top of the budget table.

<<Budget>>

Like I mentioned in the beginning, the skills associated with budgeting will take time to learn and there will be a lot of tweaking. You'll have some categories where you spend more than what you budgeted for, and you'll have some categories with leftover money at the end of the month. That's okay.
All my dollars have a job.

<<Budget>>

Make sure to only budget for what you need during the remainder of the month. If you are already half way through the month, you don't need to budget groceries for the whole month.

<<Budget>>

As a quick reminder, overspend is red and leftover money is black. 

If you overspent, you have two options. The first will be to cover the overspend by moving money from a different category. The second option is to rollover the overspending. To select an option, click on the negative red number.
Oh, I like that.

<<Budget>>

To help cover the reduced spend for each week in that month, I could rollover my Grocery category every month to build that balance over time.
I didn't think about that.

<<Budget>>

Remember the "I Forgot to Budget For" category that I added for you? I like to put my leftover money into this category sometimes to help cover small purchases that I didn't budget for, like snacks from 7-11, a watch battery for my daughter, etc.

<<Budget>>

Since our needs and lifestyle change over time, it's a good idea to revisit your budget at least every six months to see if any adjustments need to be made. Maybe your senior moves out, you get a pet, or another child is no longer participating in sports.

<<Budget>>

Don't worry if you find yourself making lots of adjustments over the next couple of months. It'll take time to really gauge what works best for you.
That's a good idea.

<<Budget>>

A good way to start building a budget is to go through your bank statements from the previous month or so and categorize each transaction. This will help you decide which categories you'll need and how much you typically spend for each category.
I will keep that in mind.

<<Budget>>

Remember, you can always send me a message or schedule a Zoom call if you need help with ANYTHING. I am here to answer your questions and support you in your budgeting journey.

<<Budget>>

For your next steps, I want you to continue practicing these new skills. Every time you get paid, make sure to budget all of your dollars. Look at the due dates of your bills and figure out what needs to get paid with that paycheck.

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

Which Option would you like to learn more about?
SIMPLE FIN
Direct Import

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.
I'm good, thanks!

Ok great! Are you familiar with how to edit column headings and re-arrange amounts in columns within Excel?

<<Accounts>>

Be sure your columns are organized in the following order:

Date / Payee / Notes / Category (blank) / Amount

The amount can either be one column, or split into separate columns, one for Payments and one for Deposits.

Thanks for selecting the Import Transaction Options conversation!

In this conversation, we will walk through the different methods for adding transactions within MyBudgetCoach.

There are three options:

Option 1: Adding transactions manually (the Introduction conversation walked through this process),

Option 2: Direct Import - using a third-party bank connection software, SimpleFIN. Once completed, when you select 'Sync' transactions will automatically be brought into MyBudgetCoach for all accounts.

Option 3: Bulk Import - uploading exports of transactions from your bank to MyBudgetCoach to add transactions in bulk for each account.
